On the site Uncommon Descent Dembski said,
 
I've pretty much dispensed with the EF. It suggests that chance, necessity, and design are mutually exclusive. They are not. Straight CSI is clearer as a criterion for design detection.

 In other words, EF always has been unable to eliminate false positives and false negatives.
 
 Scientists like Wesley Elsberry (also at The Panda's Thumb) have been pointing that out since 1999 in reviews of Dembski's book, The Design Inference.
 
 I find it interesting, as Elsberry points out, that EF was proposed as a means of identifying CSI (Complex Specifed Information) in the first place. It now seems that CSI is self evident can somehow be used to detect design without any need to identify CSI.
 
 Just more of the same. As Mark Perakh pointed out in his book, Unintelligent Design, Dembski couldn't settle on a definition for his EF in the first place. Between his first version in The Design Inference and his later version in No Free Lunch, Dembski actually removed some of what he called "essential elements" of his definition.

 It's called a mistake. Yes, it does happen from time to time....as I read alot of evo posts, many of them filled with crapola, I instinctively read them quickly. I'm sure I'm not the only person in the world to have accidently mis-read a post or article. If this were a regular thing you could rattle of a dozen or so examples -- so let's hear them.

 I barely bother reading this forum anymore because there are so many personal attacks that have nothing to do with the topic at hand. It's understandable to vent some frustration at when they act dense or stubborn, but when I read posts where behavior from other threads is brought up in order to attack someone's credibility and not to help a point in the thread, I just smack myself in the face and stop reading the thread. It's gotten ridiculous.

I read the whole thread, and it seems opinions are divided as to how big a climbdown has actually occured. 
 
 I signed up and posted a response, if anyone's interested; it's the two posts at the bottom of the second page of comments. I expect I'm way out of my depth but it'll be interesting to see what happens :)

I read the whole thread, and it seems opinions are divided as to how big a climbdown has actually occured.
That's true. If you read the last paragraph of my post you will see that Dembski has been climbing down from the first. He removed an "essential element" of EF, and now he has removed EF completely.
